questions.text: Which of the following best describes angiosarcoma?
questions.solution:
Angiosarcoma is a malignant neoplasm. It is a vascular tumor arising from the endothelial cells.

Benign vascular tumors are characterized by well-formed vascular channels lined by normal endothelial cells. Whereas, malignant vascular tumors are characterized by poorly formed vessels with cellular atypia.

Related Pearl: Classification of Vascular Tumors and Tumor-like Conditions

Benign Neoplasms, Developmental and Acquired Conditions
  • Hemangioma
    • Capillary hemangioma
    • Cavernous hemangioma
  • Pyogenic granuloma
  • Lymphangioma
    • Simple/capillary lymphangioma
    • Cavernous lymphangioma (cystic hygroma)
  • Glomus tumor
  • Vascular ectasias
    • Nevus flammeus
    • Spider telangiectasia (arterial spider)
    • Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasis (Osler–Weber–Rendu disease)
  • Reactive vascular proliferation
    • Bacillary angiomatosis

Intermediate-grade Neoplasms
  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Hemangioendothelioma

Malignant Neoplasm
  • Angiosarcoma
  • Hemangiopericytoma

questions.text: Which of the following vascular tumors are not derived from endothelial cells?
questions.solution:
Hemangiopericytoma is not derived from endothelial cells. It is a malignant vascular tumor derived from supporting cells of the blood vessels. 

Vascular tumors derived from endothelial cells are:

  • Hemangioma
  • Lymphangioma
  • Angiosarcoma

The endothelial origin of vascular neoplasms can be confirmed using endothelial cell-specific markers such as CD31 or von Willebrand factor.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true neoplasm?
questions.solution:
Cystic hygroma / cavernous lymphangioma is a true neoplasm. It is a benign vascular tumor arising from endothelial cells.

Options A and B: Nevus flammeus and port wine stain are vascular ectasias which are not true neoplasms. They are congenital or acquired malformations.

Option D: Bacillary angiomatosis is non-neoplastic reactive vascular proliferation in response to opportunistic bacilli.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common form of vascular ectasia?
questions.solution:
The most common form of vascular ectasia is nevus flammeus.

Vascular ectasias are the conditions involving the dilatation of blood vessels. They can be congenital or acquired malformations or hamartomas. Telangiectasia is the permanent dilation of small blood vessels. They lead to red lesions in the skin or mucous membranes. 

Various types of vascular ectasias are as follows:

  • Nevus flammeus (birthmark): Pink/purple flat lesions on the head or neck. They regress spontaneously.

Image showing nevus flammeus in a newborn:

  • Port-wine stain: A special form of nevus flammeus. It thickens the skin surface. It grows during childhood and does not fade with time.

Image showing port-wine stain in a child:

  • Spider telangiectasias: They are pulsatile and blanch with pressure. These commonly occur on the face, neck, or upper chest. They are associated with hyperestrogenic states, such as pregnancy or liver cirrhosis.
  • Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (Osler–Weber–Rendu disease) is caused by mutations in genes related to the TGF-β signaling pathway. It is characterized by dilated blood vessels with thin walls that bleed easily. There can be bleeding from the mucous membranes of the nose (epistaxis), tongue, mouth, eyes, and the gastrointestinal tract.

The image below shows multiple flat non pulsating telengiectasias in a patient with Osler-Weber-Rendu disease:

questions.text: A young girl presents with recurrent seizures, mental retardation and a skin lesion as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the facial port-wine stain as seen in the image is characteristic of Sturge-Weber syndrome.

This is characterized by a triad of:

  • Facial port wine nevus - usually found in the distribution of the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve 
  • Glaucoma
  • Ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomatosis (LAM) - can lead to seizures, mental retardation or hemiplegia and are seen as intracranial tram-track calcifications on CT as given below.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about hemangioma is true?

choices.text: Capillary hemangioma is the most common type of hemangioma
Cavernous hemangioma usually regresses completely by 7 years of age
Juvenile hemangioma is infiltrative and does not regress spontaneously
Pyogenic granuloma is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus

questions.solution:
The most common type of hemangioma is capillary hemangioma.

Hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors of infancy and childhood. They are of the following types:

  • Capillary hemangiomas are the most common type. They occur in the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and mucous membranes of the oral cavities and lips.
  • Cavernous hemangiomas are composed of large, dilated vascular channels. They are more infiltrative and frequently involve deep structures. They do not spontaneously regress.
  • Juvenile hemangiomas/strawberry type hemangiomas of the newborn are extremely common. They arise in the skin and grow rapidly for a few months, and usually regress completely by the age of 7 years.
  • Pyogenic granulomas are capillary hemangiomas that present as rapidly growing red pedunculated lesions on the skin, gingival, or oral mucosa. They bleed easily and are often ulcerated. It is not caused by bacterial infection.

questions.text: A child is brought by her parents to the OPD with complaints of a swelling on the right thigh. Further evaluation led to the diagnosis of capillary hemangioma in this patient. What is the most appropriate next best step?

choices.text: Explain about the risk of malignant transformation of the tumor
Test the child for retrovirus infection
Enquire about history of exposure to polyvinyl chloride
Assure the parents about spontaneous regression of the tumor

questions.solution:
Capillary hemangiomas are present from birth and initially increase in size, but many eventually regress spontaneously. They are generally benign.

Images show the gross and microscopic pictures of capillary hemangioma:

questions.text: A patient with bilateral pheochromocytoma is diagnosed with von Hippel-Lindau disease. This condition is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
von Hippel–Lindau disease is associated with cavernous hemangiomas. These vascular lesions are commonly found in the cerebellum, brain stem, retina, pancreas, and liver.

Cavernous hemangiomas are large, cavernous blood-filled vascular spaces separated by connective tissue stroma. They are infiltrative and involve deep structures. They do not regress spontaneously. 

The given image shows the microscopic appearance of cavernous hemangioma:

questions.text: Which of the following vascular lesions are commonly seen in patients with Turner syndrome?
questions.solution:
The vascular lesions commonly seen in Turner syndrome are cavernous lymphangiomas of the neck.

Cavernous lymphangiomas (cystic hygromas) are massively dilated lymphatic spaces lined by endothelial cells and separated by connective tissue stroma. They are typically found in the neck or axilla of children and rarely in the retroperitoneum. They can be enormous causing gross deformities around the neck.

Image shows cavernous lymphangioma of the neck associated with a girl having Turner syndrome:

questions.text: A middle aged male patient presents with a swelling on his left thumb as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements about this swelling is false?

choices.text: It is caused by a bacterial infection
It is a type of capillary hemangioma

questions.solution:
The given image shows a pyogenic granuloma. It is not caused by bacterial infection. The term pyogenic granuloma is a misnomer as it neither contains pus nor is it a granulomatous lesion. 

These are capillary hemangiomas that appear as red pedunculated lesions on the skin, gingival, or oral mucosa. They are most commonly benign. They tend to grow rapidly, bleed easily and are often ulcerated.

Histologic image of pyogenic granuloma:

questions.text: Granuloma gravidarum is a type of ________.
questions.solution:
Pregnancy tumor or granuloma gravidarum is a type of pyogenic granuloma that occurs infrequently in gingiva of pregnant women. 

These lesions may spontaneously regress, especially after pregnancy, or they may undergo fibrosis. Occasionally, they require surgical excision.

questions.text: Which of the following vascular tumors arising from arteriovenous structures is involved in thermoregulation?
questions.solution:
The vascular tumor arising from arteriovenous structures involved in thermoregulation is glomus tumor.

These tumors arise from modified smooth muscle cells of the glomus bodies which are specialized arteriovenous structures involved in thermoregulation. They are benign but extremely painful due to abundant nerve fibers.

Histopathology shows branching vascular channels separated by stroma containing glomus cells in nests:

questions.text: What is the most common site of glomus tumors?
questions.solution: Glomus tumors are most commonly found in the distal portion of the digits, especially under the fingernails.

questions.text: A 46-year-old HIV-positive female patient presents with fever, weight loss, and cutaneous lesions as shown in the image.  Microscopic examination reveals capillary proliferation and neutrophilic infiltration. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the microscopic findings suggest the diagnosis of bacillary angiomatosis caused by Bartonella henselae.

Bacillary angiomatosis is a vascular proliferation in immunocompromised hosts caused by opportunistic gram-negative bacilli of the Bartonella family like Bartonella henselae and Bartonella quintana.

These lesions can involve the skin, bone, brain, and other organs. They contain stromal neutrophils, nuclear dust, and causal bacteria. Histology shows capillary proliferation with endothelial cells exhibiting nuclear atypia and mitosis.

Modified silver (Warthin-Starry) stain is used for demonstrating clusters of tangled bacilli.

The given image shows histologic appearance of bacillary angiomatosis:

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV seropositive male presents with skin lesions over the distal portion of the lower limbs as shown in the image below. Biopsy shows a lesion composed of proliferating spindle cells along with small vessels and spaces containing red cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histopathological findings are most suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma.

Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) and is highly associated with AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome). Classic Kaposi sarcoma occurs in older men of Eastern European and Meditteranean descent. It has the following three clinical stages:

  • Patches- red-purple macules on the distal lower extremities
  • Plaques- patches progress to large violaceous raised plaques. Lesions spread proximally.
  • Nodules- Lesions become nodular with more neoplastic features. This stage also progresses to involve nodes and viscera.

Diseases caused by HHV-8 infection primarily in patients with HIV infection include:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Multicentric Castleman disease (MCD)
  • Primary effusion lymphoma (PEL)

The given image shows sheets of proliferating spindle cells:

questions.text: Which type of Kaposi sarcoma is most commonly seen in patients with HIV infection?
questions.solution:
AIDS-associated or epidemic Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is an AIDS-defining illness, and worldwide, it represents the most common HIV-related malignancy.

Four forms of KS are recognized, based on population demographics and risks:

Type Classic Endemic African  Transplant-associated AIDS- associated epidemic KS
Epidemiology

Older men of eastern European and Meditteranean descent

Not associated with HIV

 HIV seronegative individuals Solid organ transplant recipients HIV-infected individuals
Clinical features Skin plaques and nodules Lymph node and visceral involvement Cutaneous, mucosal and visceral lesions Lymph nodes involved

questions.text: A patient with vague upper abdominal pain is diagnosed with hemangioendothelioma of the liver. What is this classified as?
questions.solution:
Hemangioendothelioma is classified as intermediate-grade neoplasm. It encompasses a spectrum of vascular neoplasms with clinical behavior intermediate between benign well-differentiated hemangiomas and anaplastic angiosarcomas. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Vascular Tumors and Tumor-like Conditions

Benign Neoplasms, Developmental and Acquired Conditions
  • Hemangioma
    • Capillary hemangioma
    • Cavernous hemangioma
  • Pyogenic granuloma
  • Lymphangioma
    • Simple/capillary lymphangioma
    • Cavernous lymphangioma (cystic hygroma)
  • Glomus tumor
  • Vascular ectasias
    • Nevus flammeus
    • Spider telangiectasia (arterial spider)
    • Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasis (Osler–Weber–Rendu disease)
  • Reactive vascular proliferation
    • Bacillary angiomatosis

Intermediate-grade Neoplasms
  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Hemangioendothelioma

Malignant Neoplasm
  • Angiosarcoma
  • Hemangiopericytoma

questions.text: An elderly male working in a factory manufacturing PVC pipes is at risk of developing which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Hepatic angiosarcoma is associated with carcinogenic exposures to polyvinyl chloride.

Angiosarcoma is a malignant endothelial neoplasm that primarily affects older adults. The tumor often involves the skin, soft tissue, breast, and liver. Angiosarcomas are locally invasive and can readily metastasize.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common causative agent for lymphangitis?
questions.solution:
Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci are the most common agents responsible for lymphangitis.

Lymphangitis represents acute inflammation elicited by the spread of bacterial infections into lymphatics. It is manifested by red, painful subcutaneous streaks (the inflamed lymphatics) and painful enlargement of the draining lymph nodes (lymphadenitis).

Filariasis causes obstructive lymphedema and chronic lymphadenitis.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes Milroy disease?
questions.solution:
Milroy disease refers to heredofamilial congenital lymphedema.

Causes of lymphedema:

Primary lymphedema:

  • Simple congenital lymphedema
  • Heredofamilial congenital lymphedema (Milroy disease)

Secondary or obstructive lymphedema:

  • Malignant tumors obstructing lymphatic channels
  • Surgical removal of regional groups of lymph nodes, e.g., radical mastectomy
  • Postirradiation fibrosis
  • Filariasis
  • Post-inflammatory thrombosis and scarring
